channel.title: Why does 64 bit windows suck so much?
channel.description:
This may be somewhat more on the software side, but it still has a lot to do with hardware.
OK, in 2007, I installed 64bit Vista on my Athlon 64 3500+ with 2gb of ram. It was absolutely horrid, everything was lagging, even opening the start menu had a noticeable delay. I figured screw it and installed 32 bit Vista. Everything became fast again, I would say about twice as fast as 64 bit (opening windows, start menu, switching between firefox and visual studio etc). I eventually went back to 32 bit XP for a while, but that's not important.
When Windows 7 RC1 came out, I installed the 64bit edition on the same Athlon 64 3500+ with 2gb of ram. Surely it would be faster, right?! Not a chance, same problem as Vista x64, everything was sluggish. So I installed Windows 7 RC1 32 bit, and everything became fast again.
Now, the other day my new kit arrived and I put it together. Quad core Phenom, 4 gigs of ram etc. I install Windows 7 RTM x64, and holy shit it's just as slow as my old computer. I raged and installed Windows 7 RTM 32 bit, and of course everything is fast again.
I understand how 64 bit creates larger pointers requiring more CPU cache etc, and I understand how windows has to use Windows On Windows to emulate 32 bit for a lot of apps, but surely that shouldn't make 64 bit twice as slow as 32 bit, seemingly regardless of the specs you run it on. I want to use all 4gb of ram, but if 3.25gb of it is faster than 4gb...
WHAT THE FUCK?
ps. I have never ever had this issue with 64 bit linux.

item.title: Why does 64 bit windows suck so much?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:8, topic:301852”][quote author=light232 link=topic=398153.msg2955367#msg2955367 date=1252795820]
intel is better

[/quote]

Really? Who invented this 64-bit architecture? I’ll give you a hint, it is called amd64

I’ve never used a 64-bit windows because I imagine resolving dependencies and making pre-compiled programs work is a huge nightmare that I would rather avoid by using linux, or at least 32-bit windows. The only reason I could think for it acting like this though is either a lack of RAM, since 64-bit does use slightly more, or just a shitty port to 64-bit by microsoft, and the latter seems much more likely.[/quote]
I have used 64-bit Windows 7 for a while now, and have no problems with it.

Read full topic
item.source: Why does 64 bit windows suck so much?

item.title: Why does 64 bit windows suck so much?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:22, topic:301852”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=398153.msg2960028#msg2960028 date=1253128235]

64 bit cpus predate amd64

There were 64-bit processors on markets all around the world about 10 years before amd64…

Who invented [size=20pt]this[/size] 64-bit architecture? I’ll give you a hint, it is called amd64

I was careful with my wording for just that reason. ;D

shame they suck donkey dick now though, its like us English we invent a lot of sports but we suck at them
[/quote]Shame you don’t know what the fuck you’re talking about. AMD Phenoms aren’t really made to be high-end, they are there to fill a hole between expensive mid-range intel cpu’s and intel high-end cpu’s

that gap doesnt need to be filled you go mid range or you go high end, end of[/quote]That’s why they sell so well…

Read full topic

item.title: Why does 64 bit windows suck so much?
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

Unhandled:

Sorry I cba to spend twice as much for a comparable product just because it’s got a good ol’ Intel sticker on it.

this.

most Phenoms are a black edition, which has an unlocked multiplier (an overclockers dream), u see intel had these, on their quad extreme series which IIRC costed over 1k$ USD minimum. just a regular intel quad core, with the ability to overclock it better.

the phenoms can’t compete with the i5/7/9 series, but they do with the Q/QX, and cheaper.

item.title: Why does 64 bit windows suck so much?
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:16, topic:301852”][quote author=sanga282 link=topic=398153.msg2955928#msg2955928 date=1252832966]

Did you know that Windows Server 2008 R2 is only 64bit?

what do you mean is only
[/quote]
They removed support for 32bit

[quote]Windows Server 2008 R2

Main article: Windows Server 2008 R2
A second release, Windows Server 2008 R2, is to be released on October 22, 2009.[24] According to the Windows Server Team blog, retail availability will be September 14, 2009. [25] Windows Server 2008 R2 reached the RTM milestone on July 22, 2009.[26] Like Windows 7, it is built on Windows NT 6.1. New features include new virtualization features, new Active Directory features, IIS 7.5, and support for 256 processors. Removed features include support for 32-bit processors and booting from MBR hard disks. On July 22, 2009 Microsoft officially announced that they had released both Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 to manufacturing. The RTM build is already available for TechNet and MSDN users.[/quote][/quote]
oh i was reading that as you thought there was something better than 64bit and windows hadnt done it, also im pretty sure they do have 32bit we had it at work unless it wasnt R2

Read full topic
item.source: Why does 64 bit windows suck so much?

item.title: Why does 64 bit windows suck so much?
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:11, topic:301852”][quote author=runescape3dude link=topic=398153.msg2955882#msg2955882 date=1252827467]
Did you know that Windows Server 2008 R2 is only 64bit?
[/quote]
what do you mean is only[/quote]
They removed support for 32bit

Windows Server 2008 R2

Main article: Windows Server 2008 R2
A second release, Windows Server 2008 R2, is to be released on October 22, 2009.[24] According to the Windows Server Team blog, retail availability will be September 14, 2009. [25] Windows Server 2008 R2 reached the RTM milestone on July 22, 2009.[26] Like Windows 7, it is built on Windows NT 6.1. New features include new virtualization features, new Active Directory features, IIS 7.5, and support for 256 processors. Removed features include support for 32-bit processors and booting from MBR hard disks. On July 22, 2009 Microsoft officially announced that they had released both Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 to manufacturing. The RTM build is already available for TechNet and MSDN users.

Read full topic

item.title: Why does 64 bit windows suck so much?
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Yeah I’ve never noticed any problem with just plain old Windows running slower or anything.
In terms of programs, mine run a lot faster (most of them are 64bit programs which are designed to run a lot better 64bit).
And I’ve never had a problem with 32bit or older programs not working for me, even on W7.

Except for daemon tools, they just released one that supports W7 and it’s their pro version and the crack is really fucking weird.

But yeah I don’t know what the fuck people are talking about when they complain about stuff not working etc.

Sucks for you though =/

Read full topic
